metadata.title: Convert Mbps to MB/s – Bandwidth & Throughput Accurate
metadata.description: Convert megabits per second (Mbps) to megabytes per second (MB/s) or mebibytes per second (MiB/s) with standards-based bit-to-byte math and quick sanity checks for downloads, lab tests, and SLAs.

mbps_to_mb_s_decimal.label: Mbps to MB/s (decimal)
mbps_to_mb_s_decimal.description: For ISP plans, cloud transfers, and SLAs that use decimal prefixes; divides by 8 using the bit/byte definition from NIST and ISO/IEC 80000-13.

mibps_to_mib_s_binary.label: Mibps to MiB/s (binary)
mibps_to_mib_s_binary.description: For OS and engineering tools that report mebibits per second (Mib/s); divides by 8 with binary prefixes defined by IEC/ISO 80000-13.

fields.label: Throughput in Mbps
fields.helpText: Use for ISP plans, speed tests, or SLAs expressed in megabits per second (decimal prefixes).

fields.label: Throughput in Mib/s
fields.helpText: Use for engineering tools or OS counters that report mebibits per second (binary prefixes).

introduction: Convert Mbps to MB/s or Mib/s to MiB/s instantly so you can compare ISP plans, validate lab tests, or translate engineering counters without guessing the factor.
We anchor the math to the NIST bit-to-byte definition (8 bits per byte) and clarify decimal versus binary prefixes to keep audits, SLAs, and screenshots aligned.
Field-level cues mirror what network engineers, QA teams, and students expect when translating between marketing bandwidth and real-world file throughput.
methodology: Bits to bytes uses the standard 8 bits per byte per NIST and ISO/IEC 80000-13; Mbps to MB/s divides by 8 with decimal prefixes (10^6 for mega).
Binary tooling may display mebibits per second (Mib/s); dividing by 8 yields mebibytes per second (MiB/s) with binary prefixes (2^20 for mebi) per IEC/ISO 80000-13 and IEEE 1541.

Match the method to your source: ISP and cloud plans are almost always decimal, while OS performance monitors, iPerf, and some firmware counters can be binary. Note the prefix choice for compliance or SLA documentation.
examples: 300 Mbps ÷ 8 = 37.5 MB/s, which is the theoretical max download rate before protocol overhead.
1,000 Mbps (1 Gbps) ÷ 8 = 125 MB/s, a common target for wired gigabit tests.
500 Mib/s ÷ 8 = 62.5 MiB/s when reading a binary-prefixed counter in a lab tool.

faqs.question: Why do I divide by 8?
faqs.answer: There are 8 bits in a byte. Mbps measures bits per second; dividing by 8 converts to bytes per second using the NIST and ISO definitions.

faqs.question: Should I use MB/s or MiB/s?
faqs.answer: Use MB/s for decimal sources like ISP plans and most marketing specs. Use MiB/s when your tool explicitly shows Mib/s or binary prefixes. Keeping the prefix consistent avoids reporting errors.

faqs.question: Does protocol overhead change this number?
faqs.answer: Yes. Ethernet, TCP/IP, and TLS overhead reduce real file throughput. The conversion here is theoretical; expect lower observed speeds depending on protocol, latency, and loss.

faqs.question: Are these factors compliant for SLAs?
faqs.answer: Yes. Using 8 bits per byte with documented prefix choice (decimal or binary) aligns with NIST and ISO/IEC 80000-13. Note the choice in SLA records or audit notes.

faqs.question: Can I reverse the conversion from MB/s to Mbps?
faqs.answer: Yes. Multiply MB/s by 8 to get Mbps for decimal prefixes, or multiply MiB/s by 8 to get Mib/s for binary prefixes.

glossary.definition: Decimal data rate equal to 1,000,000 bits per second.
Decimal data rate equal to 1,000,000 bytes per second, used for file throughput and transfers.
Binary data rate equal to 1,048,576 bits per second (2^20).
Binary data rate equal to 1,048,576 bytes per second (2^20), often shown in OS and engineering tools.
